direct report to MOCOM

Kaiser Jeep notified MOCOM of strike at subcontractor

Cause: "Failure to reach agreemtn on new contact"

Company will not attempt to have supervisory and office cross picket line." Before violence, company claimed 80% and then 100% production with scabs and supervisory workers.

"Said company is the single source supplier, furnishing the Commander's Cupola Body and Cradle Castings to Chrysler in connection with subject contract"

Company/Organization: Budd Wheel Co. (subctractor to Ford) [same folder as above]

Company/Organization: Cobey Co / Perfection Steel (subcontractor for Kaiser Jeep)

Cause: "The company and union have resolved their differences concerning overtime work." "Work stoppage was caued by a dispute over a time standard in the crankshaft department a the Getty St. plant. Members of United Auto Workers Local 113 will take a strike vote at 0930 hours on 12 Aug 66." "Concerning your questoin 'why did they strike?', the plant shut down for normal vacation period[...] During this time of shut down ,the plant made some production rearrangement changes. [...] Continental informed the union that they wanted to re-time study some of the operations that were affected by the rearrangements made during the shut down." Union walked off, wildcat.
Outcome: Company backed down.
Notes: Memo prepared for General on "why did they strike?" Continental motor corp an important choke point?
Strike mentioned in "Procurement & Production Directorate Daily Squib". Produces engine for 10 ton truck.
No strike or strike report? More case of teamsters organizing at a contractor, consequences, aftermath.
Kaiser Jeep reported strike at subcontractor Dana Corp

Company/Organization: Detroit Diesel Engine, Div of GMC
Notes: Details from note in Blaw-Knox folder.

Outcome: "Three year contract expiring 10-31-69, with yearly wage increases of 15, 12 & 14 centers per hr. Employees also given a second week vacation after 3 yrs & a third weef after 10 years service."

Cause: failure to agree to subcontracting language. 50 employees laid off recently.
Notes: one teletype, very little info.

Outcome: "3 year agreement from date of signing 27 cent] per hour, plust 5 [cent] per hour estimated fringe benefits"

Cause: "Disciplinary Action - Workers left jobs in sympathy"
Outcome: "Wildcat Employees returned to work as soon as 2 week suspensions had run course."
Notes: "Company maintained delivery schedules on Dept. of Army contracts with production and shipment from Memphis, Tenn. Plant. No delays experienced." "The work stoppage is 'Wildcat' in nature. Union officials have instructued workers to return to work, however, employees have ignored such pleas and are refusing to report for work." Army Tank-Automotive Center command concurred with company recommendation to move production to Tenn plant.

Cause: Expire contract. "Wage reates are the major issue of contention."
Outcome: Wage rate increases, holidays, changes to health insurance.

Cause: Breakaway from IAM; initiial contract negotiation
Notes: [Is this an independent union?] 27 June 66 Bellmore to Command General US Army Tank Automotive Center: "immediate action […] requesting that plant removal action of the four rough terrain loaders be initiated due to urgen requirement." Teletype: "NLRB field examiner currently investigating unfair labor practices charge filed by union. Completion of NLRB investigatoin expected by 2 Sept but doubtful if outcome of investigation will affect primary dispute over terms of new labor management contract." Teletype July 66: "No progress made and strike by tool & die crastmen union continues with no end in sight. Productio ncontinues at normal rate with only 19 striking employees and local area teamster drivers observing picket line." Loaders shipped 7 July 66; as of 2 july union considering DOD request to move, while DOD looked for "non-union trucking or rail" to move them. 8 july letter from contract specialist: it is imperative the four (4) completed Rough Terrain Loaders [...] be shipped immediately. [...] The vehicles are required to support a major overseas operation. Further delay will deter mission planned." Indpendent union affiliated with National Federation of Independent Unions: teletype "Represents 19 FMC Corp employees who broke off from the IAM union and are negotiating an initial contract iwth the company. Negotiations have sporadically been held for hte past three months. Major issues of contention are seniority, pension plan, and duration of proposed contracts. [...] Contractor reports that other FMC corp employees are continuing to work and that strike will only result in inconviences for short period of time."

Outcome: Work continued despite "union trouble."
Notes: No formal work stoppage report. File closed: "Rec'd call 5 Nov 66 from (Blose) DCASR-Phila still having union trouble however plant in operation. Note closing file based on this info." Letter to A.L. Bloss, Labor Relations, Defense Contrat Administration Services Region, Philadelphia: sent work stoppage report for San Jose; "I don't see the relationship between the UAW at charleston's Plant and the International Association of Machinists at the San Jose Plant. It must be noted that the IAM at San Jose is the predominant union at this plant."; note to see comments on backside of report. Note about wage increases over 3 years plus fringe benefit improvements.

Cause: "One Grievance" - spray booths not up to standard
Outcome: "After examination of the booths, the Committee [company, union local, safety engineer from UAW intl] declared them to meet health and safety standards. The Union body ratified the findings at a mass meeting held 3 April 1966 and the workers returned to work at 0700 hours on 4 April 1966."
Notes: Not clear if changes were made to spray booths after walk out and before inspection.
technical advisor to Franklin Company claimed he did not receive full pay. Dept of Army found he had.

Cause: "Management describes the issue as work habits or ways and how to work. In particular, this involved one group of employees that management contends was not meeting previous production quantities on the same job. The Union members contend the issues are riding of employees unmercifully, forced speed-up in production, and threatened loss of jobs."
Notes: Union leadership took stance against strike. Started with 10 employees walking off job afternoon 21 april 1966, production shut down following morning. Delayed delivery of nike-hercules missile trialers directly from Fruehauf; delayed delivery of v-100 from Cadillac Gage Co, Fruefauf sub-contractor for hulls and turrets

Cause: "Expiration of contract - Failure to negotiate new contract - Contract Language - Economics"
Notes: Location produced "truck and personnel carrier components", but contract numbers "Unknown, DCASO, Ft Wayne is administering no contracts at this plant and no inspection assist has been requested." [bc subcontractor?] [folder contains strike reprot from lima electric, seems misfiled]

Outcome: New contract
Notes: Still waiting on hundreds of containers due for final delivery on 17 march 67. No work stoppage report filed. Did they learn abt after the fact?

Cause: "It is to be noted that this plan has been working a six (6) and seven (7) day week for approximately two (2) years."
Outcome: "Immediate pay raise of 5[cent] per/hr and 8[cent] raises in the following 2 yrs. Increased sick pay. Cost of living escalator clause and a 9th paid holiday."
Notes: 33,900 "mandays lost" [that box isn't usually filled out].
Construction machinary and equipment

Cause: Refusal to upgrade Contract Accessory Testers to same salary level as recently upgraded Engine Testers.
Notes: 60 testers walked out 16 May, sympathy walkout 6 June, 3-1 strike vote 9 june, negotiations deadlock 23 June. GE considered staggering normal July vacations, but DOD contract specialist feared this would cause another grievance. Affected delivery of tail rotor tranmission assembled, main gear drive assemblies [not sure for what vicks].
Returned to work 5 Oct under threat of walk out if contract not settled by 17 Oct.

Outcome: Settlement Reached

Union Local: URW 200? [based on pen found on ebay]
Notes:
8/8 "Termination of Strike at Goodyear, St. Marys, Ohio" - "Telephone conversation 8 August 66, bewtween Mr. R. haverman, Mgr., Governemtn Sales Department on the above subject established following information" - strike started in cure room, all personnel walked out; limited operations until 6 aug, when no operations. Operations back 7 aug at midnight. "Mr. Haverman terminated conversation by stating that this was the official notification."  From Wilfred Bauknight, Spec Ass't to Director, Procurement and Production

[Overall, gives impression that Goodyear possibly not on great terms with DOD agents.]

Cause: "Both Management and the International Representatives were not fully aware of the reason for the walkout. However, the International Representative feels that the local union committee and local management are not altogether agreeable on policy and procedure."
Notes: Prime and subcontractor for "S S manifolds" (?) for aircraft including MacDonald F4H.

Company/Organization: Harvey Aluminum (sub for Hydraulics Research & Mfg Company)
Notes: Very interesting transcript between Dusty Rhoads, AVCOM, and Bellmore. Rhoads points out that union wants dismissed workers hired back, but management claims they have violence problem. Very anxious that production is behind schedule, affecting vicks for Vietnam, despite 75% personnel working. Bellmore advises they can't get involved at labor relations level b/c strike is abt union recognition - with established local, they 'can go through internaitonal.' But newly recognized is a different thing.

LTV subcontractor, LTV informed MAMP of potential strike. "At the present time the Union has declared a ban on working overtime, and this is expected to cause some slippage in the delivery schedule of the subcontract."

Company/Organization: Hercules Engine div of Hupp Corp
Outcome: New contract: "Two year ocntract expiring 10 Aug 67. Economic package estimated at 29 cents over term of agreement; improved contract language."
Notes: Made engines for trucks. Memo 1 oct 65 "ATAC requirements of 10 HP and 14 HP MD Engines": 10x order of 10hp engines,  accelerated delivery of m131a5 tanker trucks 'due to SEA situation.' (Later memo says original delivery schedule would work for trailer, but concurs with increased total orders of engines?) Engines are for m131a5 tanker ttrailer [why does trailer need low hp engine?] November study found it impossible to meet demand for both 10hp and 14hp engines, and that one or another would suffer set backs. Some pressure to move up assembly time. Strike in August, Bellmore kept day-by-day handwritten notes on calls with federal mediator and latter's talk with company. Attention to details of union ask and company's forecast. Federal mediator report on suspension (shortened) and firing (upheld)

Outcome: "Two year contract, with wage increases approximately 16[cents] each year and change in fringe benefits."
Notes: made "angle assembly-pontoon". Union refused DOD request to ship completed items thru picket. "All but 273 pieces have been shipped. The remaining 273 pieces are manufactured, pakcaged and ready for shipment. The purchasing office is currently determining hte urgency of the tiem and whether removal action is required."

Cause: "Contract negotiations, wage benefits, pay incentives""All economic issues were favorably settled for all concerned. A 30[cent] p/h wage increase for all employees. Expiration date for new agreement 27 Mar 1969."

Outcome: "Three (3) year agreement was ratified on 2-26-66. Wage package provides a 32[cent] per hour increase."
Notes: Made "Latches and handles for tanks and trucks"
Kaiser sends telex on 12/22/1966 informing of wildcat. Not information abt why. "There wil lbe no interruption in our performance as a result of this strike."

Outcome: "the strike at Keco Industries ended when Iron Workers Local 522 agreed to end the strike in exchange for Keco dropping a $214,00 damage suit which was filed in Common Pleas Court on 19 May 1966 approximately half of the Productio nWorkers had returend to work during the week ending 27 May 1966 which indicated that the strike was broken. Nearly all striking workers plus new hires were reported at work on 31 May 1966."
Notes: Made air conditioning equipment. Contractor hired scabs. "The contractor is attempting to employ workers from labor surplus areas to replace striking workers."

One memo from Industrial Labor Relations Office, Lawrence Kiefer. No info otherwise.

2/11 "TWX received 11 Feb 66 from Hughes advising that due to 2 itesm on purchase from Koehler/Dayton not being delivered due to strike ,aircraft on Contract DA 23-204-AMC-02849(T) now on assembly line would be affected. This information apssed to Robert Morrison this date. Mr. Morrison caleld abck at 11:40 AM 11 February advising that he would follow through on their part but that the strike had been settled at 12:05 PM (Dayton time) and that workers would return to work on Monday 14 Feburary 1966. Impact on any AVCOM items will not be known until Contract Due-In Inquiries are received on 14 February."
Earthmoving equipment.
Kaiser subcontractor, kaiser communicating with DOD. letter from Medium Vick Branch Procurement & Production Div to Commmanding general: strike at Lakeviewsettled. PARTIAL NEED TO RESCAN

Customers 85% commercial 15% government. Bellmore handwritten note: 'should lay off governemnt intervention at this time' [??]. Strike interrupted delivery of fan assembly by Lear Siegler

Company/Organization: Lansing Drop Forge Company (sub to Kaiser Jeep)
Cause: "Application of work standards and incentive plan."
Outcome: "Grievances settled regarding application of work standards and incentive plan."
Notes: Made "lifting shackle" for Kaiser Jeep and "Pintle hook mounting bracket" for Holland Hitch Co. Kaiser reported work stoppage.

Outcome: "Agreement Reached & Ratified 30 April avoiding a Work Stoppage" "Wage increase of 9 cents per hour for unskilled workers, 10 cents for semi-skilled, and 11 cents per hour for skilled were agreed on effective 1 May 1966."
Notes: Reporting from Morrison, Industry Labor Management Relations Officer, kept close tabs on negotiations, including distance between labor and management offers.  Union authorized strike for midnight, 30 april 66.

Cause: Work stoppage occurred […] as a result of contract expiration. Renegotiations […] No vilence is being experienced and office and supervisory personnel remain on the job. The major issue is wages." Chrysler claimed no delay in delivery. Rok Island DOD says opposite 8 March: Any delay in settlement wil leffect delivery schedule of 60 ea Cupolas in April, May and June. Approximately 800 castings have been delivered with a balance of 1600 on order."
Notes: Chrylser sub making cupulos for m60 turrets. work stoppage report looks particularly primitive. One of the first drafts? 4 March: "Economic issues have been settled."

Cause: Contract renegotiation opened 12 Sept. Warning sent of potential for work stoppage on expiration of contract. Contract renewed without incident.
Notes: Contract renewed without incident. Interesting to see ciruclation list for a report abou, in essence, a successful renegotiation

Cause: "Economics - management wants to freeze the cost-of-living factor[,] Union is adamantly opposed"
Outcome: "Union membership ratified a 2 year L-M Agreement on 30 June 66. General wage increase on 10[cent] per hour and 9[cent] per hour were granted effective 31 May 1966 and 31 May 1967. cost of living base was frosen [sic] 2 years. Fringe benefits included improved insurance, increased pensions and 4 weeks vacation after 20 years."
Notes: Made "electrical power equipment, inverters, alternators, generators, test equipment for semi-conductors." More interesting!: sole source for "entire electric system for CH 46-A helicoptor"(sub for boeing) and "Turret gun Mount" for prime contractor Servo Voters and 2 Bell products: chopper and torpedo. Bellmore [?] handwritten notes abt calls on subject; details about how union felt abt COL moratorium; Cleveland tank plant had enough equipment to fill july order of m155 sheridans.

Cause: "Difference in interpreation of L-M Clause on right to strike" "Economic pakcage (Ins, Holiday, Vacation, etc) and unions demand for a strike clause to alleviate inadequacies present in grievance procedure.
Notes: Made generators, strike report notes that defense contracts were 40% of production for company.

Company/Organization: Lindberg Hevi-Duty and Hevi-Duty Electric Co.
Notes: Made "Electric Regulators". Handwritten notes include notes abt Holland Hitch. [Holland hitch "first tier", lindberg "2nd tier"?] "14000 ready for pickup Teamster drivers refuse to cross pick lines"

Cause: Initial union organizatoin, failure to agree to contract.
Outcome: Handwritten note: closing file b/c 1) initial labor organization + company and union "unable to establish a labor contract" and 2) company got court order against union, 3) company maintains orders with non-union workers
Notes: On contract for nearly 50k rear view mirror assemblies. Handwritten notes about once a month: in October, month of final delivery, company keeping orders on schedule with 35 non-union workers. File closed 4 April 66 for reasons in notes under "outcome" column.

Cause: Contract Expiration - Strike Impasse is over management right to subcontract clause."
Outcome: 3 year agreement 20 feb 66. "3 percent economic package. Contract languaged was changed incorporating a clause protecting management's right to determine subcontracting. The 'escape clause' was retained in the contract maintaining the Non-Union shop. An annual wage reopener clause was negotiated. [...] Seventy-five percent of employees returned to work" 21 feb. All employees back 23 feb.
Notes: Made "bonded rubber bushings" for Army dollys and rubber components for Chinook for Boeing and UH-1B (Huey) for Bell. Strike reduced Bell's ability to ship completed product [date?]. 158 items on order board! Mass picketing 4 Jan, court injuction - union allowed ingress-egree voluntarily. Bellmore memo 4 jan 66: "All indications are that this company is laoded with defense work for the Army, Navy, Air Force and DCAS organizations. Prior to the mass picketing, there were approximately 50 to 60 supervisors working in the plant on orders carrying the highest DO ratings." 5 jan work stop report: union used mass picketing tactically on 15 dec and 4 jan to halt all but a handful of employees from entering facility; report includes copy of "Manufacturing News article" that "caused" mass picketing on 4 jan. Article accuses union officials of wrongdoing and ordering members to "illegal" mass picketing, signed "Committee Believing in Fair Union Activity and Practice" [looks like a planted article] 11 Jan reported be using 200 supervisors, technicians, salareid personnel working 10hrs/day to produce 70% capacity (projected, no idea of outcome). 25 jan: 2 more employees return to work, but Bellmore doesn't take it as encouraging bc defections had potential to set off more energetic picketing. 31 jan Kiefer (ind labor rel officer) memo: rank-and-file voted down proposal to return to work under old contract while negotiations continued (283 to 80). 11 feb: 75 union members crossing line, "Vandalism and violence is occurring companion to the strike. Mass picketing is  taking palce in disregard of injunction issued by Erie County Judge. County Sheriff's Office is maintaining ingress and egress of personnel and vehicles." Prioritized delivery of parts for Huey, Apollo program, at expense of "Red Ball" (?) (repair parts?: https://www.dvidshub.net/news/255758/evolution-amcom-formation-us-army-aviation-and-troop-command-atcom-part-iv-aviation-logistics-and) for air force and Polaris missile and host of other DOD contracts. 60% normal DOD. Negotiations stalled over subcontracting on 14 feb 66. Notes throughout abt problem with subcontractor - something to do with bad materials and excess scrap.

Cause: "Disciplinary action by the Contractor against two shop stewards has been given as the cause of strike." "Walkout sanctioned by local union but not by Natoinal Office."
Notes: Notified by ACOM, Larry Fieffer, by phone. Notified by Kiefer of resumption. "Conditions of settlement not known at this time." "No impact on production scheduler, consider this labor dispute closed."

Company/Organization: Manistee Iron Works, Div of Michigan Tool Co
Notes: No strike report, not a lot of info. Forecasted to last until middle of august, and looks like they were correct."

Produced electric motors for Cleveland Tank Plant. Sub for Webster Engineering Corp, prime contractor for Army Corps of Engineers. Did not take note of cause or results, strike does not appear to have impacted production at all.

Company/Organization: Massillon Spring & Rivet Co (sub for Kaiser)
Outcome: Sub for Kaiser Jeep; Kaiser informed about strike 18 Oct 1966. "Teletype dated 21 December 1966 has been received from Kaiser Jeep Corporation advising that there will be no interruption in production as a result of this strike."

Company/Organization: Modine Corp (sub for White Motors Corp)
Notes: Just one type-written note dated 6 Dec, handwritten notes added after. Produced radiators and related components, White Corp out if strike continued to 16 Dec. For "Priority 02 M600 series 2 1/2 ton truck for SEA". "Negotiations between company and union continue early agreement looks possible"

Cause: "Primarily economic - pensions, wages, vacations, etc. However, hours of work week, duration of contract and job evaluation are also issues.
Outcome: 3 year contract; "Company secured right to schedule Saturday O/T, however, can be excused if they give acceptable reason by Thurs. noon."; "Economic items: Total package estimated at 47.3 cents per horu over a 3-year period. Wage increases of 10 to 16[cent] per hr. the first year, 10 to 16[cent] per hr. the 2nd year, and 10[cent] per hour across the board the 3rd year. Pensions, insurance and vacation were improved. Good Friday will be the 8th holiday. A Seleted group of jobs will be reviewed for job inequities."
Notes: Produced "Machine CUtting Lathes (Standard and Numerical Control)". FMCS made proposal accepted by both sides 3 Jun 66. 1 june report: "Management states they are also expecting to make contact with the I.A.M. Regional Director at Cleveland, in an attempt to resolve the dispute. Management claims the local Union leadership is not able to control the Union membership. The intensive effort to resolve this dispute follows an agreement reached wit hthe Bargaining Committee which was immediately rejected by the local union membership." Order board lists 14 contracts, 9 different companies or military agencies. 12 may report: "Parties are still apart on four issues of whic hthe most significant is a company demand for the right to schedule Saturday work for a 48-hr work week. Both partis are adamant on this issue."

Outcome: 3 year contract. "Option check-ff. $.35 per hour increase over a 3 year period."
Notes: Produce ""Transmissions, differentials, transfers and axles." 1 Nov Bellmore mssgs Defense Contract Administration Services office Atlanta for info on Mutual Truck Parts Co strike. 16 Aug report: "Negotiations broke down after a meeting held 15 Aug. The main obstracle to settlement is the 'check-off' issue. Work stoppage began and picket lines set up at 0001 hours, 16 August 66." [check off likely = dues check off]

Outcome: No details except strike averted.
Notes: report 15 march: "The CIRS was in Watertown to look over the company's prime contracts and subcontracts and has found that there is approximately $3,900,000 Governmetn backlog at the plant. This backlog consists of items such as spare parts and kits for the Air Force and Navy and hydraulic pumps, starts, and motors under sub-contracts from the primes, such as Sikersky, Northrop, the Boeing Co. (Vertal), Grumman, Kamen, and many others." parts used for helicopters, airplanes, and m107 and m110 rifles. "There are many many orders at this plant for SEA and at the present time it is quite impossible to list all contracts and orders as they total some 2700."  "The CIRS has arranged with bot hthe company and the union for ingress and egress of DoD personnel in the event of any strike action on the part of the union; also has secured an agreement with the union that, i nthe event there were any items i nthe plant of sufficient impact to the Government, removal would be accomplished upon formal request."  [What is CIRS?]

Report 11 may: "Anti-friction bearings (and various small metal specialities).""Contractor holds 49 active prime and subs - total dollar value $563,000 - itemization being compiled." 557 on strike at location of 749. 11 May final report: "Hydraulic Machinery, Stationary & Marine Diesel Engines, Mining Machinery." no details on outcome.

At least 3 contract: "Tank components." 4 Aug note to Bellmore: "No meeting is scheduled. Negotiations are complicated by NLB investigation of fair labor practices filed by the union." 4 aug work stoppage report: "Company and Union have been meeting periodically with appreciable progress. Negotiations are complicated by NLRB investigation revolving around employee petition for de-certification election."

Outcome: Union and mgmt reached agreement on dispute.
Notes: "DCASR-SF currently administering some 47 prime contracts with contractor for R&D and replacement parts on specialized vehicles and self properlled artillery peices. IMpact on DOD contracts dependent on status of contract and whether machine required." "Because of short duration of the strike and the small number of stirking employees, no extensive impact was experienced on DOD contracts."

Cause: "The Pacific Coast Engineering Company is a member of the Pacific Coast Shipbuilders Association which was struck by the International Brothwerhood of Electrical Workers Union, (IBEW), on 4 Nov 1966." [see note for full transcript abt larger strike]
Notes: Sub to FMC.  "Construction & repair of ships, drilling platforms, cranes, dredges, etc." Other crafts did not strike with, so only 3 on strile and "Thus, the company now has practically a full work force with only the three memebrs of the IBEW continuing to remain off the job." File closed. Full transcript of explanation, 15 nov report: "1. The Pacific Coast Engineering Company is a member of the Pacific Coast Shipbuilders Association which was struck by the International Brothwerhood of Electrical Workers Union, (IBEW), on 4 Nov 1966. 2. Approcimately 1400 members of the IBEW are involved in the dispute with an estimated 11,000 workers off their jobs as a result of the picket lines. The Shipbuilders Association represetns 13 yards in three states (Washington, Oregon and NOrthern California. 3. The strike began after the parties were unable to agree to the terms and conditions of a new labor management contract. The Union is demanding a two year contract with 5% wage and benefit increases each year. Negotiations are being resumed this date 15 Nov 1966 at the National Office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Services, Washington, D.C. This will be the first negotiation session since the strike began." 23 Nov report: "A number of local unions have now authorized their members to cross the IBEW picket line. Approcimately 350 of the Pacific Coast ENgineering Company's 450 employees are now reporting to work. Impact is still beign experienced however because major uniosn such as the International Association of Machinists are honoring the picket line."

Outcome: "New contract expiration date 29 February 1969."
Notes: "Helicopter Baldes and Rocket Booster Fuel Tubes (NASA)."
"Truck Bodies, Hyrdraulic Cylinders, and Spare Parts"

Outcome: Union failed to pass strike vote (need 3/4 yes), settlement on company's offer by default. 45 cent over 3 years (~4.5% increase)
Notes: Made rough terrain forklist trucks. 11 Feb report: "Eventual impasse and strike likely becuase of recent settlement secured by IAM from U.S. Industries, Inc., Bedford Park, Ill. (Mfgrs. of mech. & Hydraulic press equipment) which amounted to a 53[cent] package over 3 years after a 9 day strike." [pretty interesting that they're tying one outcome to another in a report.]

Outcome: Nearby town of Upland changed boundaries, gave financial concession -> closed factory in Anderson, abandoned striking workers.
Notes: Governors and automatic chokes. UAW Solidarity paper: Negotiations in '64, strike. Company abandoned facilitiy for new one in 65. Some abandoned workers found jobs in other UAW shops; others ended as dishwashers, mechanics, security guards. Company dragging feet on delivering pensions to 7 eligible. "When Local 940 struck, Boren imported strikebreakers and brought in armed private police (whom the Anderson police disarmed after His Honor, Mayor Allis fed them) and, then in January, 1965 he shifted operations on a piece-meal basis to Upland with production being performed by supervision, $1.25 labor recruited from the surrounding farms and Taylro College students working part time." "Picket line violence" published in labor papers - Local 662's Delco SParks and Indian Record Review. UAW filed charges through NLRB. Senator Vance Hartke inquires abt award to Pierce Governor Co in or before early December 1965. Local paper clipping: Pierce awarded contract from Army Mobility Equipment Center, St Louis, for governors military generator (already sub for Continental Motors). Letter from Local 940 leadership to Sen Vance Hartke on news of onctract: "We have been led to believe that the Government would not do busienss with a company that is sinvolved in a labor dispute. We have had pickets at hte Upland Plant since February of 1964." Then & Now write up from local: "We maintained a picket line at the Anderson plant unti lthe first of October of this year. We also maintained a picket line at the Upland Ssite ever since the start of consturction of the new plant, even though we had pickets at the building site the new building was constructed with the help of scabs and some union labor. We have 75 members left on the picket line or strike duty at the present time, with about half of them being women. Over a hundred or more of our members were on the picket line for months but as the strike went on and the company kept refusing to bragan, they had to find jobs to keep their homes and families together. Most of those that are left still have the determination to stick it out, if we can, unti lwe win this strike against such a ruthless ocmpany." Ends with appeal for donations to supplement strike checks for upcoming Xmas season. Sept 65 strike news release: "They have tried every strike-breaking tactic in the book, swuch as, importing goons (armed), hiring scabs, and using straight-time foremen and employees on production jobs and etc. In Feburayr of this year they moved production operations to upland, a town just 35 miles away. They built a new plant on ground donated by the citizens of upland and with the help of scabs and some union labor. Most of the building trades unions and the teamsters crossed our line with the exception of the ironworkers, who would not cross our picket line. Most of the unions had said that they wouldn't cross our line but when they saw scabs doing their work they went across it then. [...] The company has been advertising in area newspapers for workers and we have been told that they are saying that the strike has been settled and that they have signed a contract with our union." Letter drafted from US military bureaucracy to Hartke states 1) "Pierce Governor Company is the only approved manufacturer of the required engine governor." and 2) "There is no policy or practice by the Department of the Army to withhold awards from a firm solely because it may be engaged in a labor dispute. In this case the Contracting Officer determined that the contractor had the capability to deliver." 15 Oct 65 contract request language: "The contemplated procurement is for replacement parts in support of the 10 H.P. and 20 H.P. Mil Standard Enginers. This part is manufactured by the Pierce Governor Company, which is the only approved source." Another memo (Sept 64) does make it sound like "Major Procurement Branch" trying to obtain technical information necessary to shop out for other providers. Says impractical to obtain thru "formal advertising" bc technical info not at hand. Oct 65 meeting with Pierce: "to determine their production and delivery capabilites on the two governors urgently required for Mil-Std engines"; aware of recent move to Upland from Anderson; "Messrs Boren and McDonald explained the reason for their move; briefly, their Anderson Plant was too old, too expensive to remodel or modernize, high real estate taxes and continuous labor problems."; "Mr Boren pointed out production of the Novi govenor is continuing as they purchased from Continental MOtors all manufacturing rights and tools used in the process." [suggests Boren was aiming to get into military contract if he purchased governor from Continental]; "Officials of Pierce expressed interest and keen desire to secure orders for govenors direct from the Government instead of the engine manufacturers, as had been their past experience."; presented govt with cost estimate w/ 20% profit for company. 26 August 1965: "Another Contract with Pierce-Governor by MEC" for 120 governors [implies orders increased for vietnam buildup]. 24 Nov contract: ordered 6662 governors, techometer drives, gaskets; 3000 for Sharpe Army Depot in Lathrop, CA, rest bound for depot in Atlanta, GA.  Handwritten notes ~12/14/65 suggest Bellmore to sign letter to Hartke - "LCB". Telephone trascipt Bellmore with Commissioner PReston, FMCS, Indianapolis: B: have they organized at Upland? CP: UAW has picket, UMW 50 tried and failed, company working on non-union; CP: "We stepped out of picture because there was a question of represetntation. Company refused to recognize them, and we had to withdraw. [Transcript is very interesting and maybe even a bit difficult to decipher w/r/t attitudes toward labor. Is it fair to say that CP got message across to B that company is working fine on non-union basis and therefore no need to intervene (e.g., connect with Federal Mediator or NLRB)? I think possibly. But one thing that is *very* clear: these DOD bureaucrats know labor very well. They know down to the local - even down to the UMW local that tried and failed to organize Upland]

Outcome: Date of agreement, but no details.
Notes: "Controls, Switches, Coils, etc." Handwritten note 26 april 66: "Cannot obtain 'order board' from this company it is not a prime government producer." Two plants in Kentucky.

Outcome: Strike settled on negotiating team's terms
Notes: Telephone transcript with WIlliam Harvey, DCASR, Hartford, Conn: Navy issue, their reluctant to share info. "Mr. harvey believes the Navy doesn't 'take things from all angles' and they were even a little relunctant to give him informatoin when he called."; "The contract expired on the 15th and the negotiating committee had originally agreed to work on a day-to-day basis because they were near settlement. However, a dissident element in the union became aware of this and set up picket lines which prevented the first shift from going in. Some second and third shift personnel managed to get in. The company now has an injunction against mass picketing and the pickets are off. The did have some violence on the picket line yesterday. Mr. harvey did term this a wildcat strike."; "The non-economic issues have been settled but they are still working on the economic ones."; things appear to be going well.

"This is a Receiving, Identifying, Packaging and Shipping Plant." "Request was made to Local 408 for permission to ship material considered critical by the Govenrment. Permission granted when request is made by Procuring Officer." "Items processed are ignition and starter systems, generators, starters, spark plugs, capacitors, relays, voltage regulators, wire cables, sealed beam lights, electric motors and many other assemblies and spare parts."

Cause: "Primarily economic package involving wages, cost of living clause and other fringe benefits." "Several contract language changes including a Union demand to limit subcontracting have been proposed. No difficutly is anticipated in resolving these items if an agreement is reached on economic items."
Outcome: "3 Year Contract[,] Economic Package - .60 over 3 year period."
Notes: "Coiled springs." Subcontractor for Kaiser Jeep - Kaiser reporting on developments. 28 Sept: Supervisory employees producing spare parts, trucks not crossing picket. Order board: 10k+ springs on order for 7 different prime contractors. Continental Motors corp informed strike beginning.

Company/Organization: Rocketdyne Division of North American Aviation
Cause: "The Union has notified the above subcontractor that it desires and intends to terminate its collective bargaining agreement, effective 14 March 1966.
Outcome: Union returned to work, negotiations moved to Washington, DC "at the request of the Federal Mediation Service"
Notes: Sub for LTV on Lance missile program; LTV informing MAMP contracting office.

Outcome: "Company withdrew proposal and employees returned to work." "ATAC contracts in excess of $2,000,000 administered by DCASR, Detroit."
Notes: "Heavy axle assemblies [can't read]."

Cause: Discplinary action "Mr. Emery said people have been working 6 and 7 days a week and this is probably just their way of showing they would like a little time off."
Outcome: Kaiser subcontractor; Kaiser informing.
Notes: Kaiser subcontractor; Kaiser informing. "The Federal Mediation & Con Service has not been called in as yet, neither has teh State. Labor Relations people feel this particular issue at this particualr time does not warrant calling the union. They feel the union may get too bold and merely delay the return to work. They believe discretion should be used at this time." "27 Army contracts involved - these are primes. Items affected are transmissions and axels. 41 PO's. These are for spares in support of the jeep program."

Company/Organization: Russell-Burdsall & Ward Bolt & Nut Manfuacturing Co.

Kaiser did look in to. 21 September: "Company representatives in Japan and not due back until 3 October 1966, at whic htime FMCS will attempt to sc hedule a joint conference."

Outcome: Factory closure.
Notes: "Inspection fixtures, gages and templates." "Meeting held on 3 June 1966 resulted in conclusion of the strike and withdrawal of the pickets. The strike ended due to the Company officials announcement in the meeting that the firm will cease all operations on/or about 31 July 1966 and the property lease which terminates on 1 Serptember 1966 will not be renewed. No further new orders are being accepted, existing orders will be completed and shipped." 19 May strike report order board: sub for GE, Lycoming, one other I can't read: 35 contracts, majority to GE, GE cancelled majority of their contracts.
"Electrical control elements"

Cause: "Grievances on work standards and suspensiosn of employees and Union officials"
Outcome: "Remarks: Union membership ratified agreement reacheed 25 Nov."
Notes: "Bus-Ambulances, Shop Vans." dd1507 18 nov 66: "Management secured an injunction on 21 Oct 66 which limited picketing to three pickets at each entrenec.e Movement of personnel is normal since the injunction was posted." dd1507 14 nov 66: "ALL issues resolved except suspensions given 8 Union officials." letter 9 nov 1966 to white motor corp [superior a sub for white?]: you haven't provided information on strike at superior coach, will m609a1 shop van trucks be affected? dd1507 1 nov: "All issues resolved except suspensions given 8 Union officials." dd 19 oct 66: "Grievances on work standards were resolved, however, 33 suspensions of employees as discipinary saction for an unauthorized walkout are the issues remaining."; "Mass picketing has occurred with many foremen and production supervisors refused ingress. Those who entered had difficulty in securing egress. Cars were parked bumper to bumper to keep automobilies form using parking lots. Management advises one employee was beaten, tires of automobilies were deflated, 35-40 window panes have been broken, and other incidents have occurred. Management has petitioned for an injunction and the hearing will be held on 21 Oct 66. A pass for peaceful ingress and egress of QAR has been secured." [QAR = quality assurance representative?]; "Of the 71 original issues in this dispute, 38 work standard grievances were resolved. An impasse was reached on the issue of suspensions for 25 union members and 8 union officials. Parties finally agreed to suspension of 25 union members for 4 days and to pay straight base rate for one day. Impasse them [sic] developed over suspensions of union officials. Management is willing to give one weeks [sic] pay at base rate with a aletter in each personnel file. Union is insisting on pay at incentive earning rate and no notice of suspension in file. No meetings have been held since 14 Oct 66 and none are scheduled." dd 17 oct: "Trouble with picket lines on 10/17/66."; "Pickets refused entry to QAR on 17 Oct 66. However, the U.A.W. [?] Regional Director has assured the CIRS this will be changed immediately. Pickets placed one shop van across an entrance to facility and deflated tires." Order board 14 oct 66: 5 contracts, sub for 4 primes - Kaiser, White Motor, International harvester, GM. teletype 14 oct: kaiser informing on state of strike. Handwritten note ~26 oct 66: tried to reach someone at DCASR Cleveland abt strike. [a lot of information does travel between bureaucrats who are in touch with local actors, usually companies I think. Need to read for this.] 13 oct 66 handwritten notes. 15 oct handwritten notes: Company leased prop from Lima Depot to store vicks; "Labor Incident: "At the time the strike occurred the union set up picket lines at the Lima Depot to prevent the Commercials [?] from being shipped - comapny attempted to move vehicles off the depot leased property.

Cause: Teletype Kaiser to US Army MOCOM 26 Sep 66: "On 23 Sept 1966 a strike vote was taken by the local UAW-CIO unit and was authorized by a 9-1 margin. The ten day notice of strike has been given to superior by the union and if the issues are not settled by 7 Oct 1966 an authrorized strike will be called for 14 Oct 1966."
Diposition Form 1 apr 66: "The company and UAW Local #711 could not reach agreement on some 80 unresolved grievances. The majority of these grievances are in the nature of work standards."
Outcome: final dd1507 21 april  66: "The main issue of the strike, piece rate, was resolved by an Agreement to run actual time studies for a 4-month period. The Union has the right to strike after giving another 10-day notice if new method for establishing piece rates are not acceptable. The Union Committee has agree unamiously to recommend acceptance of this settlement."
Notes: Disposition form 1 apr 66: Delivered 3 out of 63 busses ambulence conversion, some with AC; "This is an Air Force 02 priority requirement. A portion of the total quantity is urgently required in SEA."; busses for Internatoina lharvester Corp and GMC; shop vans for White Motor Company, Kaiser Jeep. final dd1507 21 april  66: "The main issue of the strike, piece rate, was resolved by an Agreement to run actual time studies for a 4-month period. The Union has the right to strike after giving another 10-day notice if new method for establishing piece rates are not acceptable. The Union Committee has agree unamiously to recommend acceptance of this settlement." dd 1507 20 apr: "The major issue of job rates for piee work was resolved on 16 April, however, negotiations stalled on approximately 10 miscellaneous grievances." Handwritten notes 25 march: "HOT" penciled in red and udnerlined next to "Bus, 44 Passenger, Ambulance Conversion"; "Issue: Grievances 60 to 90 (54 on work standards)[.] Strike vote taken 21 Mar 66 97% for[.] Strike set for 21 Mar 66 [underlined red][.]" 31 mar telephone transcript, Mr Morrison, Cleveland DCASR: "Washington rumble came about as a result of mediation seeking pressure on the company from military defense levels. This is what precipitated it (opinion)."; "Mr. Bellmore asked if it would be of any value to send Colonel Hanson down there to emphasize the direct requirement of items in Viet Nam. Mr. Morrison said he would check with Mediation to see if they want this kind of help at this point."; [later] "Mr Morrison called again to say he did call Mediation and MEdiation did not think it would help at this time to have Colonel Hanson go down."

Cause: "Incentive Wage Rates, Economic Issues" (same dd15067, 8/24, says both parties were "extremely adament" on "work standards problem"). memo for Gen Lapsley (from LCB) 15 aug: "Two primary items of issue are: a. Wages [and] b. Production speed-up as claimed by the union. The company has admitted the speed-up and claims they need more production to meet competition."
Outcome: Final report not cleary legible; only lists cent and percent raises, no mention of speed up.

6 swedish company employees penciled on inside of folder, including name of VP and phone extensions for others.

9/1, Report by LCB circulated to several commands. 9/1: sub for American Machine & Foundry Co (unnamed item), Bowen-McLaughlin ("Major end item, gun, howitzer, S.P.F.T. 8" M110 [does this mean swed made the gun or BM made gun and swed made component?]); Chrysler ("final drive hub" for unnamed item, "major ten item, tank, combat, F.T., 105 MM gun, M60A1"; "Major end item, turrent, m60a1e`", unnamed item); Consolidated Diesel Electro Co (10 ton tractor truck); FMC ("major end item, carrier, mortar, 91mm, m125a1. No impact on delivery schedule, FMC has dual supplier"); Rockwell Standard Corproation (sub for Ford, unnamed item); Thomas Industries Inc (sub to Load Craft Inc., 2 1-ton chassis trailers; "these trailers or 02 priority, hawk system program). Some stated did not expect issue until November, the month the strike ended.] 

8/12 Defense Order Board List: sub to 35 contractors on 125 individual contracts. 

8/25 Report LCB to Commanding General MOCOM: parts for 105mm gun (contract ending 648), brackets, "are of a critical nature", patterns "have been removed" and Chrys looking for new source; parts for m60a1e1 not due until may 67, so no impact expected; "There is no stock for this item." meaning no stoc for Final Drive Hub part. 

8/10 memo for Bellmore: "Mr Brightbill [DCASR-Detroit] said this is merely a preliminary report. Will get 1507 as soon as it is ready. Thinks it will have quite an impact on Allison as it will impede their production. Sait it will take a whole day to get list of contracts affected."; 13 aug handwritten note on memo: "Why are they striking?" 

9/21 handwritten note, conversation with Brightbill from DCASR-Det: "Things do not look encouraging." 

9/27 Memo of Call: Brightbill wants a call back to discuss two meetings: Swedish Crucible for following day and Sparton Electronics Div, Jackson, for 5 October [I don't think this is in my list]. 28 sept memo, Brightbill called no progress. 10 Oct memo, Brightbill called to report progress. 

8/18 Memo to Commanding General, US Army MOCOM: report on impact of strike on ATAC prime contractors; "American Machine is a subcontractor of Bowen-McLaughlin-York and at the present time they are investigating another source of supply. Bownen-Mclaughlin-York, is also having a court order prepared to enable the mto remove unfisnihed material from the Swedish Crucible Steel Company [handwritten note indicates this is for "m110" howitzer]; Thomas Industries, "Mr. Thomas stated in telephone conversation that he must receive castings for Gear Boxes in four weeks or it will affect his production. As of this date Thomas Industries have not tried to locate an alternate source of supply We will suggest that they do so and if necessary, furnish a list of companies that do this kind of work. These parts are used on the Hawk Program." [what is hawk program?]. 

12/6 Memo to commanding general MOCOM: Chrysler advised in letter that strike ended on 16 Nov. [...] There has been no delay in production under the subject contracts becuase of the strike. Chrysler made certain adjustments, particularly in locating new sources for certain items." 

12/1 letter from Chrysler notifying end of strike 16 nov; "As of this date, it appears there will be no major imapct on porduction under subject controls."

11/4 dd1507: "Local 601, at a special membership meeting held 2 Nov 1066, rejected the Company's latest wage-package offer. No meeting has been scheuled. Strike status remains same."; 37 offices/individuals on circulation list. 

11/15 memo. Sid Barry of DCASR-Det called to report progress and tentative agreement, "The union is now in the process of mustering enough people for ratification to either accept or reject it. They are allowing about two days to notify everybody in order to get a legal quorum for the ratification voting so there will be no question of legality later. They have no been on strike 2 1/2 months and both company and union appear to be ready to settle." 

9/29 dd1507, forecast changed to "Indefinite." 

9/21 Memo to Commanding Gen, US Army MOCOM, from Lindbloom, Plant Contracts Section, Combat Vehicle Branch, Major items division, 21 sept: "1. Representatives of the eChrysler COrporation ahve advised on 21 September 1966 that Swedish Crucible Steel Company is still on strike. 2. It has been indicated that it might be necessary to remove other patterns from Swedish Crucible Steel Company in the near future if the strike is not settled. These will be resourced. This action will be taken t oassure continued production at the Detroit Tank Plant." 

9/12, dd1507 "No progress reported from meeting held 9 Sept 1966. Parties still very far apart over main issue of work standards. Status of negotiatoins is at an impasse. No date has been set for the next meeting. However attempts will be made by the Federal Meidator to bring the parties together again within the next ten (10) days. No impact reported." 

8/24 dd1507 from dcasr-Detroit: "FMCS has scheduled a meeting for 1000 hours on 29 Aug 1966, however, due to the extremely adamant [sic] position of both parties relative to work standards problem, an early settlement is not considered liekly.; "Forecast of duration of stoppage": "6-8 weeks"

9/1 memo from Linbloom (chief, plant contracts section) to commanding general US army MOCOM: "1. C. Stieber, Chrysler Corporatoin, advised the following on 1 September 1966: a. A new source has been developed b ythe Chrysler Corproation for P/N's 2100574, 2100576, 2100577, 7953923. This is the Vassar Electroloyd Products Company, Vassar, Michigan. Chrsyler has reported that it is expected that the new source will be able to maintain production requirements on an uninterrupted basis." 

8/26 memo to Bellmore from Mr Barry, DCASR - "Pere telecon from AWC, Mr Rowland, regarding AMP possible court action. Monday court date set 29 August 1966, for request of writ of replevin. Tuesday replevin to be served on local union in Detroit. Wednesday writ will be excercised to remove the materials from plant, regarding Swedish Crucible Steel Strike." Handwritten note: info obtained Am of 30 Aug from DCASR-Det = no court action taken yet by AMP or BMY. "Why is AMF & BMY acting so late they should ahve taken this action two weeks ago." "Reprote this latest info to J. Riley & D. McKenzie ATAC P&P 8/30"

8/18 Memo F.W. Lindbloom, Chief, Plant Contracts Section, to Command General, MOCOM, ATTN Bellmore: Chrysler Reported 8/16 subcontractor Swedish Steel still on strike, no meetings. Swed supplies 4 part numbers: 3 for Scranton Defense Plant, Enyon, PA, 1 for DTA. "Swedish Crucible Steel Company has 30 to 35 castings, P/N 7953923 [for Chrysler, DTA], at their plant. These are in a semi-finished ocndition. There are no other parts in any state of manufacture at the Swedish Crucible Steel Company." "Chrysler is attempting to locate another source. This will require the removal of pattern from the Swedish Crucible Steel Company." 

8/12, letter from M.E. Dilworth (Manager, Contracts Administration ,Defense Operations Division), Chrysler Corp, to US ATAC, attn F.W. Lindbloom (Chief, Plant Contracts Section) [designated Mr. - civilian?]:  Chrysler sub Swedish Steel labor dispute notified 8/10; "we are advised that the labor dispute arises as a consequence of contract expiration on 18 July 1966. Renegotiations started approximately 1 June 1966 and work stoppage occurred at 9:00 AM, the morning of 10 August 1966. The major issue involves an economic package. The last meeting was held on 9 August 1966 and was comprised of State, Federal Mediators, Union and Mangaement, with no progress reproted. Approximately 200 employees are affected by the dispute. There has been no violence experienced and office and supervisory personnel remain on the job." "Chrysler's Production Control has checked all castings that are received from Swedish Crucibel Steel Company and are covered through September and byeond on all except three (3) parts: One (1) at Detroit and two (2) at Scranton are covered through August, but we will need castings on these three parts by August 20th to allow for machine cycle time to meet September schedules."

8/23 wire Kaiser to US Army MOCOM: Kaiser informed DTA of strike at Swed Steel on 8/17

8/17 wire Kaiser to MOCOM: "[...] been advised by our subcontractor Holland Hitch Co [...] Mich that the Swedish CCrucible Steel Co supplier of steel castings for holland hitch was struck". holland supplier of 2 different "pintle assembly" 

8/15 Memo for Gen Lapseley from Bellmore: "Concerning your question "Why did they strike?", the existing labor agreement between the company and the UAW Local 601 expired 17 July 1966. The company and the union have been in continuous negotiations prior to their contract expiration date of 17 July and up to the time of the strike on 10 August 1966. [...] Two primary items of issue are: a. Wages [and] b. Production speed-up as claimed by the union. The company has admitted the speed-up and claims they need more production to meet competition."

8/26 Memo from Edward J. Rowland, Special Assistant for Labor Relations [CG USAMC Washington DC - means?]: GMC-ALLISON, Cleveeland (M109) SP 155mm, obtained 22 castings and removed patterns 16 August 1966 on basis of court order. August deliveres of M109s will be completed. Contract for critical casting for body of panaramic telescope M117 oon M109 has been placed with Lebanon Steel Foundry and samples ahve been received. No indicated impact on September delivery of M109s. Impact report for Bowen-McLaughlin-York (M110) SP 8 inch Howitzer; AMF (M110) sub contractor; Chrysler (m60 series) Tank; FMC (M113, M577, M106, M125) vehicles will be submitted from USAMOCOM-LR. Data and information have been coordinated with this command." 

8/30 wire from Kaiser to US MOCOM: "We have been advised by Holland Hitch Company that although the strike at Swedish Crcible Steel Company, Detroit, Michigan is still in effect, they have resourced steel castings and tseel forgings and will be able to take care of our requirements. As a result of the above, this will be our final report." 

8/19 Office Memo for Bellmore: "Mr Corey, M60 Project Manger's Ofc [...] called ref Sweidsh Crucible Steel strike. I read him the 12 Aug 1507 and your letter of 18 Aug in which you forecasted a minimum 30-day strike duration. However, he requested the latest status since the Project Manager was concerned since their product was involved. Mr. Sid Barry gave me the following info and I relayed it back to Mr. Corey. Mr barry said no meetings are scheduled, and there have been no meetings (one meeting was held spearately between the Fed MEdiator and the company and another between the Fed Mediator and the Union, but nothing came out of it.) Mr Barry said appoximaely have hour before I called him, he talked to the Vice President of the company who said no meetings have been scheduled, nothing firm. The Vice President was not in direct contact with the union or the Fed Mediator and was playing the 'waiting game.' It was Mr Barry's guess that possibilit yof meeting next week could happen; said by next week someone may be hurting; but right now this is just his guess." 

8/25 memo from Limbloom, Chief of Plant Contracts Section, to Commanding General MOCOM: Previous information submitted in our leters dated 15 and 18 August 1966 is subject to correction as follows: a. Castings for four (4) each aprt numbers were previously reported as being furnished by Swedish Crucible [...] under Contract No. DA-11-199-AMC-648(W). Based on the receipt of more ocmplete information, Swedish [...] furnishes castings for 16 each part numbers under Contract No. [same as above] and castings for two (2) each aprt numbers under Contract No. DA-11-199-AMC-662(W). 2. Four (4) each of the 16 each part numbers under Contract No. [648] are of a critical nature as follows as to their stock condition in support of the continuation of manufacturing: [all brackets w/ diff part numbers. 2 will be out 1 oct 66, one will be out 16 oct, one will be out 21 sept]. 3. The patterns for P/N's [all parts above] have been removed from Swedish Crucible Steel Company. Chrysler Corporation is looking for a new source. 4. There is sufficient stock on hand on the following 12 each parts to cover requirements through November 1966 under Contract No. [648]: [4 brackets, 2 doors, 1 hub, 2 housing, 1 shaft, 2 cover]. 5. The following parts are furnished under Contract DA-11-199-AMC-622(W). Delivery of the end items under Contract [662] begins in May 1967. These parts do not have an impact as of this moment. [rotor cradle, lid]. 6. Chrysler Corporation included in their reporting Part Number 2100013, Final Drive Hub. This is being furnished under Contract No. DA-111-022-AMC-2681(T). This is a contrat executed by the U.S. Army Procurement Detachment, Chicago, Illinois. There is no stock on this item."

3/30/66 Memo DCASD Hartford: "The meeting was totally unproductive and further attempts by the Mediators to bring the parties back to the bargaining table have met with resistance from Company and Union. [...] As of this date DCAS Inspectors will again enter the plant to perform their normal duties, through arrangements made by the CIRS. The nion has steadfastly refused to allow DCAS Inspectors to pass through the picket line, since 15 November 1965. Present arrangements do not inlcude a change in the Unions' stand. This report will be the final report to buyers listed on the ORder Board unless and until significant negotiation progress is made. Agency heads will, however, receive the prescribed weekly report." 

3/29/66 1507: "Stalemate, after more than 50 meetings" [same or similar long distribution list]

1/21/66 memo DCASD Hartford: no progress, looks indefinite, company says "final offer" on table; pickets at Troy, Michigan Vickers plant, Teamsters International authorized informational pickets at Vickers plants; "both parties met yesterday with the Mayor of Waterbury and reports indicate no concessions were made by either." 
 
1/14/66 memo CDCAD, Harford: "The January 6 bargaining session was completely unfruitful and future prospects were obscured by the NLRB issuance of a letter notice of complaint against Vickers charging violations of Taft-hartley sections 8(a) 1() and (5). The Union filed three charges against the Company which were dismissed and later recalled when a fourth charge by the Union was investigated. It is now reported that the Company has initiated action for filing a charge with the NLRB against the Union for failing to 'bargain in good faith.'

Weekly narrative reports from DCASD, Hartford, from Nov 65 to Jan 66. Covered negotiations, union barring inspectors, NLRB moves.
2/18 1507 "Seals and Gaskets"

Outcome: 2/17 1507 "8[cent] hr across board wage increase, insurance program improvements - 2 1/2[cent] hr vacation improvements - 3 wks after 10 yrs - sick leave 3 days paid @$15 per day"
Notes: 2/17 1507: "air cleaners" for tanks". Just 1 file in the folder.

Outcome: 7/26 1507 "wage increase, 12 1/2 cents per hour for each of 3 years. Pension - $1.00 for week in 3rd year [...] A wage increase was agreed upon for 12 1/2 cents an hour for each of the 3 years of the new labor/management contract. The company agreed to contribute toward the union pension, one dollar per week for each employee starting with the 3rd year of the contract."
Notes:
7/22 1507 "union demand is for a wage increase of 12 1/3 cents per hour for each year of a 3 year contract. The company has offered 12[cent] per hour for the 1t year, and 10[cent] an hour for each of the next 2 years. The union is also demanding that the company pay on [sic] dollar per week for each ? toward the union pension plan to begin in the 4rd year of the contract."

7/21 handwritten note: Prime Contract DA-25113-AMC 09074(T) priority 20 "Item: Truck, Wrecker, 1600 GYW 4x2"

6/22 Handwritten note "? Are they urgently required???" followed by something about requesting plant removal related to urgent SEA requirements

3/9 1507: "Various engine housings"; "Local union president originally discharged one month ago. Dispute carried thru grievance procedure up to arbitration stage when settlement effected whereby president returned to work subject o six month probation. When 55 minutes late in reporting for work for second time following return was again discharged 1 march 1966. All shifts completed work on 1 March 1966 but a picket line established 2 March 1966 and no work done since. This strike is in violation of labor agreement and illegal Int'l representatives of union have not been able to get people abck to work and the picket line has been honored by the Teamsters Union."; "Tiscompany is a sub-contractor for continental Motors which in turn is a sub of Kaiser Jeep - and is producing an Oil Filter and Cooler Base Housing for the engines which Continental is making for Kaiser. The company is also a sub-contractors for the Allison Division of General Motors under multiple Air Force Contracts.

Company/Organization: Westinghouse Electric Co, Copper Wire Div
Cause: 9/7 1507: Changes in methods and alleged abuse by foreman"
Outcome: 9/7 "Wildcat Strike (Settlement)": "The strikers returned to work at the insistance of Union Officers as it was claimed that they had no right to strike over excessive over time. In the meantime, on August 30 the Company penalized the strikers one day for their actions. This was a disciplinary action in accordance with the Union contract. [...] Very little time lost and no impact upon government orders." [written by Ralph Runke, CIRS - what is CIRS?]
Notes:
9/7 "Wildcat Strike (Settlement)": "The strikers returned to work at the insistance of Union Officers as it was claimed that they had no right to strike over excessive over time. In the meantime, on August 30 the Company penalized the strikers one day for their actions. This was a disciplinary action in accordance with the Union contract. [...] Very little time lost and no impact upon government orders." [written by Ralph Runke, CIRS - what is CIRS?]

8/31 "Wildcat Strike": "According to the information received by the CIRS this walkout could have been caused by the various changes in methods instituted by the company, plus the fact that due to the demand of copper wire and copper material these men were working from 10-15 hours per week overtime and apparently were getting a bit fed up with the overtime policy."; "According to company officials the imapct upon government orders will be nil as they figure there will not be more than 3000 manhours lost through the workers actions."

N.d., handwritten note: "Note: General Strike all westinghouse plants 1 Nov, 1966"

[Heading hard down a copper industry-Vietnam War rabbit hole.]

Outcome: 11/17 memo CIRS "Strike (Settlement)" - independently agreed to same terms as national agreement, even though shop was not subject to national level agreements
Notes:
11/17 memo CIRS "Strike (Settlement" - "The rank and file of IBEW Local 1833 met the afternoon of 15 November 1966 to discuss and vote on the IBEW contract as negotiated at the national elvel. While the local 1833 does not come under the national agreement they nevertheless did agree to accept the economic conditions as agreed upon in Pittsburgh. They ratified the common expiration date of 9 November 1969, which was part of the national agreement. They also agreed to accept the improved movement under the seniority set up. By this we mean the transfer and elibility of employees from one department to another or from one plant to another .They nevertheless retained teh same type of a local contract for their M&R shops."; "The company manufactures electronic tubes used by the government's various agencies. These orders constitute approximately 50% of their production capacity. There were a total of 9600 mandays lost, of which approximately 4800 were on government contracts." 

11/15 Narrative - "the strike continues at this plant and even though the IBEW reached a national agreement at Pittsburgh, apparently the officers of local IBEW 1833, Elmire, N.Y. are in disagreement with the naitonal settlement to the extent where they prefer a union shop and not the accumulative service time as agreed upon. They also want assurance that there will be no discremination against any union member because of their participation in the strike.  2. Nevertheless, the union is submitting to its rank and file the national agreement with some local issues included which have already been negotiated for approval the afternoon of 15 November 1966. 3. It is the opinion of the CIRS that the rank and file will accept the proposal as submitted and agreed upon at the national level. Because of previous observations we feel as though the majority of the rank and file were not interested in a strike at this time and are somewhat anxious to return to work. [...] Removed materials 10 Nov - 15 cartso n tubes. If strike continues, will need to make similar removal "within a week or ten days time.; Thye union is very cooperative in allowing shipment of vital government material." 

"Record of tubes shipped 10 Nov 1966 under DoD supervision in accordance with union agreement" - 10 "customers" listed

11/7 Narrative - "the IBEW nationally struck the Westinghouse facilities officially on 1 Nov 1966. However, Westinghouse, Elmire plant did not go out until 3 Nov 1966. They had previously agreed to work on a day to day basis only to have another union, namely the American Flint Glass WOrkers representing the workers at the Westinghouse plant in Bath, N.Y., some 37 miles from Elmire, picket the Elmira facility and soliciting the IBEW local to honor said picket line. The CIRS is of the opinion that the rank and file voted to make their honoring of the Glass Workers picket line official, therfore struck of their own accord." "The company devotes approximately 50% of their production effort on government orders. Attached order board if or infomration only, and in the event of needed clarification, the CIRS, Rochester, N.Y. should be contacted." 

order board - looks like order board but different; lists as many or more DOD departments as it does contractors.

11/8 WSJ clipping "Westinghouse, Striking Union Heed U.S. Plea - "Defense Output Called Hurt"; "The IBEW struck at midnight Oct. 31 when its natioanl contract expired. The contract only covered 800 workers in 22 repair shops that service Westinghouse-built equipment. IBEW members at 11 manufactuing plants also have joined the strike, and two others have been shut by roving IBEW pickets.  Altogether, Westinghouse says 8318 IBEW members are on strike and 436 are staying out becuase of pickets. A key issue in the negotiations has been the union's demand that the national contract cover all plants where it has memebrs. It has 14,000 members among Westinghouse employees, most of them at 24 manufactuing plants. IBEW units at these plants currently bargain individually for plant-level contracts only." The IBEW was an original member of an AFL-CIO effort at so-called 'coordinated bargaining' in the electrical industry this year. All AFL-CIO unions which had contracts with Westinghouse or General Electric Corp. banded together to support one another in bargaining. The group began with eight uniosn and later grew to 11 when negotiations with General Electric got tougher last month. Eventually, all uniosn which had national contracts with the two companies settled except the IBEW with Westinghouse. Geogre Meany, president of the AFL-CIO called a meeting of the heads of the 11 unions last week to discuss the Westinghouse situation. Afterward, he issued a statement pledging support to the IBEW. Beside the IBEW work stoppages, Westinghouse said it has a total of 6,240 members of other uniosn on strike at four other plants over other issues." 

[above raises the question - should westinghouse ibew "general strike" get its own row in the table?"
